Doesn't Matter

Notes: I scaled all parts by 7X

This assembly is designed to rigidly mount a LeapMotion controller to the top of an Epson Moverio BT-200 display. There are two components to the assembly. One attaches to the front of the Moverio using the nose piece screw. The second holds the LeapMotion and attaches to the first piece using an M2 fastener.
The resulting assembly can be used to incorporate hand and gesture tracking to facilitate user interaction with BT-200 apps. A link to an example project combining the LeapMotion with the BT-200 is forthcoming. Check back soon!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

200 microns

Notes: I created this assembly using a Cube3 printer with white PLA filament. The resolution was set to 200 microns with a hollow fill and line pattern (default Draft part settings). The result is still quite accurate and fit together well with no trouble.

Finish Parts - Smoothing and Fasteners After finishing the print, I recommend using some sand paper (any grit you prefer), to finish the edges of the pieces and remove any jagged edges or strings remaining after the print. Since the dimensions of the part are exact, it's possible that the parts might fit together very tightly. Use the sand paper to remove a couple of layers of material to increase the ease with which the parts fit together. The two parts, LP_Front_Piece and LP_Holder_Front are designed to be screwed together using M2 fasteners. The LP_Front_Piece has a polygonal hole through which an M2 spacer can be inserted. I recommend using the following spacers: http://www.ebay.com/itm/M2-Black-Nylon-Hex-Female-Female-Standoff-Spacer-6mm-8mm-10mm-12mm-Hexagonal-/201322955283?var=&hash=item2edfc88213 Any standard M2 screw (of length 10mm or shorter) can then be used to attach both components together. Assembly - LP_Front_Piece The LP_Front_Piece attaches to the front of the Moverio. 1) Remove the small screw holding the nose piece into the Moverio frame. 2) Place the LP_Front_Piece onto the front of the Moverio. The small bump should fit securely into the gap under the nose piece ridge, with the hole then lining up with the nose piece screw. 3) Replace the small screw, securely tightening the LP_Front_Piece to the Moverio frame. Be careful not to over tighten the screw too much. Front View of LP_Front_Piece attached to the Moverio Side View of LP_Front_Piece attached to the Moverio Underside of LP_Front_Piece showing the nose piece screw holding the piece to the Moverio Assembly - LP_Holder_Front The LP_Holder_Front securely holds the LeapMotion controller itself as well as attaches to the LP_Front_Piece on the Moverio. 1) Securely push the LeapMotion controller (front first) into the LP_Holder_Front. The LeapMotion should securely "snap" into place. 2) Slide the LP_Holder_Front down onto the LP_Front_Piece and fasten both components together using an M2 nylon screw. Front view of complete assembly Rear view of complete assembly Side view of complete assembly

title: Stove push or select button for Whirlpool oven

description.text: This object is the tiny push button for the electronic control center.  There are 6 of them on the stove and they are all needed for the proper functioning of the appliance.  Unfortunately they are also very fragile especially when they get older.

This was adapted from thing:10539 by Kim Tyson - Thanks to Mark Gaffney we now have all the buttons back in our stove. The front panel is shown in the picture with 3 buttons out for inspection. This adaptation of Marks version simply alters the parametric numbers
he provided. This version has been righted on the platform but I recommend printing using a platform/raft unless you make the button flat. Be very gentle when separating the raft ( I use an additional thin layer on my rafts) and gently sand the stem using something like 600 grit paper so that it fits gently in the stove. If you have to push hard you didn't sand it enough and will have to start over if you can't extract it from the oven. Luckily all broken bits fall off inside and don't plug the holes. I made 3 of these. They work best printed 1 at a time - painfully slow print for such a small object - but hey, it works. I have replaced 3 of these on my stove. The originals are grey - I guess I could paint the new ones but the colour coding looks cool. IE you could use red for the cancel button.

comments.text: Cool! My version was a bit of a quick 'n Dirty approximation but yours looks super detailed.
comments.author: M_G

author: tyson

description.text:
Various experiments in assistive kayak paddling grip designs. These are a continuing work in progress and none of these work as well as I would like. Some of the designs may be effective for casual paddling but I don't think they're adequate for open ocean kayaking. They are designed to fit Werner carbon shaft paddles. I used 1 inch webbing and Velcro OneWrap for convenience. Eventually I expect the designs will use sewn straps that are easier to tighten or integrate into gloves. Original design files are available on Onshape. Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter.com)
-- eSun Transparent Magenta PETG
-- eSun Transparent Blue PETG
-- eSun Transparent Yellow PETG
-- 3D Solutech Transparent Blue PETG

title: Simple Shelf for medium sized Corelle Ware (8.5" dia plates, bowls, etc)

description.text:
This is a simple space saving shelf that goes over your stack of Corelle plates or pasta bowls letting you place things on top.
I designed the top in a honeycomb pattern to save plastic, and the end result was a weight of 39g of PLA, making this design cost about $2.
Compared to the original design, I added crossbeams around the border so it wouldn't bend or sag as much, but they could easily be made thicker to hold more weight. Currently it holds 4 or 5 plates without sagging. If anyone would like me to modify the model to be stronger, just ask.

description.text:
These brackets will support up to a 1.9 inch (~48mm) pole, pvc, or dowel. I am using a piece of 1.5" SCH40 PVC, which fits perfectly because it is 1.9" on the outside. This holds my filament spools perfectly.
Of course, you can use these with smaller diameter rods, poles, and pipes as well. The bottom cradles smaller poles so they don't move around too much.
I will update with photos when I have it mounted in it's permanent home. :)

author: JimyT

description.text:
The goal is to be able to drop in an off-the-shelf plastic frosting bag and go. The shaft squeezes the bag and out goes the frosting. This design is functional but still needs work. The metal tip and plastic nozzle are available at hobby and grocery stores. The rest of the stuff (except for the motor) were sourced from my misc. parts bin. Not sure where the gears originated but they shouldn\'t be hard to find (or replace).
The treads are lasered into the plywood. The squeezing mechanism is new, the frame is derived from Will\'s.

Gears:
26 teeth
22mm diameter
1/4\" bore 1/2\" long nylon bushings (flanged), 1/4\" inside diameter
1/4\" shaft, collars and coupler. (shafting is not yet cut to length)
M6 threaded rod and M6 nuts
Motor is the same used in the MakerBot extruder.

comments.text: Further complicating matters is the tapering of the bag, so that the squeezer has to move faster as it moves down the bag if a consistent flow of frosting is required. An untapered bag would eliminate this complication.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The MakerBot guys have done several variations using a syringe. My goal is to be able to do it with a bag that can be just dropped in...though I agree that using a bag probably exacerbates the issue.
comments.author: MakerGear

comments.text: How about a cylinder designed to accept the bag and nozzle!
comments.author: MakerGear

comments.text:
Could be the bag is expanding and messing with your precision. Maybe a syringe or some other cylinder
&
amp; piston design would work better. should be printable too...
comments.author: dcb

comments.text: Also, I may try to couple this with the tube squeezer that was posted recently.
comments.author: MakerGear

comments.text: Ha! Good question. The next step is to really use it...as in make some designs and print them. Printing with frosting is kind of tricky because it seems the frosting compresses quite a bit so it is hard to turn the flow on and off...will post the output once I have it :)

author: Genapart

description.text: It's a gigglin' light-up pumpkin! Perfect to bring to school and trick out your desk. The lid comes off and there is a CR2032 battery/LED holder inside. There are two size options to chose from.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.25 mm & .29 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: The bigger one shown is printer in Wooden PLA on a Z18 (@.25mm layer thickness, and 25% infill). The rough texture is do to fact that I am still experimenting with the settings while using the wood filled material. The smaller one shown is printed in ABS on a Zortrax M200 (@ .29 mm layer thickness and solid infill).

Assembly I used a 5mm RGB LED to get the flashing effect. A trick to get the lid on - There is one bump on the lid of the pumpkin that is smaller than the rest. Use this little bump to key into the corresponding little space on the pumpkin. To light it up - Place the LED legs vertically down the flat sides of the battery. The longer leg goes on the smooth side. If you bend the legs a little toward each other first, they will make a better connection. While holding the sides, slide the battery and LED vertically down into the holder in the pumpkin. Viola! Your very own happy to glow pumpkin. Hot glue helps if you want a more permanent attachment.

100mm powder basket
Hole is 10.5mm at the top, tapered 1 degree 11/06/15 NOTE: If you printed one of the .mfp files before this note, there has been a minor change that greatly increases the stiffness of the part, and only add .1CC of Kevlar to the print If you are printing on a Markforged Mark One, I highly recommend you download one of the included .mpf files and print from a USB. I put a lot of work into the fiber layout and you won't get that with just the .stl. Revisions:
Rev C features larger (cooler looking) slots and the REV B updates
Rev B has been updated with a larger (1.125mm) bottom edge fillet that markforged will not remove with "thin features" turned off and better surfacing on the cutaway at the back In the .mfps, each basket uses 17.3cc nylon (REV C) or 18.4cc nylon (REV B) and 2.4cc kevlar (both revs). The picture of the rev B is an old fiber layout.

This is a side-release buckle or parachute buckle that works with 3/4 inch straps or 'webbing'.
I modeled this so I could print a replacement for a broken clip on my pack. Originally printed in PLA, which has been surprisingly functional so far, but I've reprinted in PET+ which has a much better flexible quality to it and should last far longer.
Prints best with support everywhere, especially for the female side of the buckle.

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

50-150 micron

40%

Notes: Is most functional when printed in PET+ or similar, but also works in ABS, PLA, etc.

This small little pumpkin is great for kids! The face is carved out I have a single extruder machine, but I switch filaments to do: 1) The first 1.5mm in green or black
2) The next 1mm in GlowFill
3) The rest in orange. This means the carved out face glows in the dark! I tend to print the first two colors on .20 and move the orange down to 0.10mm. If you have Simplify3D, take advantage of the multiprocesses to make this even easier! I'm attaching the .STLs of six different faces. In addition, I'm including my template which you can use to carve out your own faces.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 / 0.20 / 0.10

Infill:

I usually do about 30% infill

Notes: The first 1.5mm (0 - 1.5mm), I print in green or black
The second 1mm (1.5 - 2.5mm) I print in GlowFill
Then the rest (2.5mm on) I print in Orange. I use Multiprocesses in Simplify3d to make the filament changes easy. The 3D Printing Nerd has a tutorial of that approach on his YouTube Channel https://youtu.be/ZHe2_h1nQG4
You can put a string through the loop in the vine to make the pumpkin a pendant.  In addition, you can glue a pin back to it to make it a festive pin! : )

I used Blender to make my default pumpkin. My faces came from either Blender or from the Shapeways 2D to 3D App (we converted black and white Sharpie drawings). I set my faces up so they end 2.5mm up and then I subtracted the face from my pumpkin template. More on my blog at:
http://tgaw.com/wp/2015/08/24/carving-my-pumpkins-in-blender/
You can also order prints from my Etsy shop at: https://www.etsy.com/listing/243463111 It's easy to carve out new pumpkin faces, so let me know if you want to make a custom face!

comments.text: Vicky how does this work?  Looking at Joel's video you save 3 gcode files from S3D, but reviewing the files it wants to do all of the startup script routines like homing all axis and auto bed leveling.  That would not work.  Shouldn't there just be a pause at each layer height you want to change the filament?  The pause moves the hotend out of the way and locks so you can load the filament and extrude manually enough to purge the previous color?  Sorry for being such a noob, but even google points back to Joel's videos and I'm just not seeing it as something that will work.
comments.author: danzca6

comments.text: Greetings!  With these kind of items that are flat, I do run them as three separate prints.  I'll run the first print which under Advanced, I have it set up to stop after 1mm.  It does run all the usual shut down procedures (for taller prints, I customize my gCode-- more on that below), turning off the extruder and dropping the bed, etc.
comments.author: danzca6

comments.text: That helps a lot.  Detail that was never defined in Joel's video or others he did with deadpool logo and such.  I am just concerned that homing Z after the first section is done and starting the second is a potential issue.  My Robo3D stock uses the hotend to home, but I now have an IR height sensor.  So it might not register off the part depending on the size relative to the offset of the part.  Even if it still used the hotend I would have to add something to the startup gcode to heat the nozzle after homing so the hot nozzle doesn't push into the part while homing.  Also I am currently using auto bed leveling probing G29 at the start of my prints to adjust for the bed since I don't have thumb screws for better manual bed leveling.  So if I switch to MESH leveling that would eliminate that issue since I would just need to home Z at the beginning of the prints and the bed contour will be already saved in the firmware.  I think your second option of relative to absolute positioning is the way for me to go.  This help a ton Vicky.  I thank you for taking the time to further explain the details.  I wish that would be better explained in the video.  Your blog post is excellent and I will have to experiment with inserting objects next.  You are very talented.  I love learning new things like this.
comments.author: VickyTGAW

description.text: This Python script will let you generate arbitrary box partitions that you can then laser cut.

Invoke like: $ python2 gen_partition.py 203 38 101 > out.svg The numbers are in order:
  • inner width of the box (in mm)
  • width of the flaps you want for gluing (in mm)
  • height of the partition (in mm)
  • (optional) arc width control angle
    • Then laser cut the resulting svg. Pink lines should be done at a lesser power, and parallel with the corregations. Black lines are full power. (Note the render on thingiverse is cropped to a square, the actual file is wider than that and opens fine in InkScape.)

It's here! The world's first easily customizable, inexorably modular, supra-comestible,
mobile tool corral. And it's cheap.
A small, $12 furniture dolly is at its core. I chose 2x4 framing because it is cheap and gives me a surface to mount just about anywhere easily with cheap drywall screws. This suits my purposes and gives me a specific place to put each tool. Tools tend to clutter my workspace and then elude me when they are needed most, so I am trying to fight back with a bit of making.
I also incorporated a magnetic bar and some sturdy parts trays. A lot of the structure is re-purposed from what I had lying around. It cost me around $50 at Harbor Freight, not counting filament and tools.
The top array utilizes a quad frame of 7/8" (22.3mm OD) dowels spaced 60mm apart (from the centers.) 1/2" schedule 40 PVC will also work but is not as snug. The tool holder blocks snap in and can be screwed or riveted in place.
I also added a luggage carrier that allows the whole thing to rest at a 25 degree incline for wheeling it up a ramp.
I would be interested in doing a customizer for this concept, but I am crap at SCAD, so please message me if you are SCAD proficient and would like to collaborate. Everything is modeled in 3dsmax, using splines and booleans, so should translate pretty well. Enjoy!

description.text:
Ive now had my printer for a couple of weeks and found a couple of issues. nothing big but as I find them , I'll make / download new parts
I noticed that one of my prints had a "ridge" part way down. A quick inspection revealed that the two 8mm rods at the back of the printer moved ever so slightly - on checking, the retaining holes varied in size from about 8.1 - 8.4 mm .
So I designed these replacements. and a "setting tool, for measuring and aligning the rods to the back wall.
The bottom ones are fiddly, but they are worth changing.
An added point is, that after changing them, the bed levelled in seconds.

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 -medium

Infill:

20%

Notes: I increased the wall thickness to ensure stability.
The bottom ones are flat and the top ones have a spigot to aid rigidity

Just off the press! Final fitting I deliberately left the holes tight, then reamed them out with an 8mm drill - the holes were spot on after that ( with care)
Top ones were easy to change, but you will need to remove your bottom circuit board to gain access to one of the bottom ones, so unplug your machine!!! The image shows one of the top ones in its final place.
Designed in Autodesk Final Design

title: Printable parametric mold for oogoo feet for reprap printer

description.text: Create a printable parametric mold for casting rubber feet using oogoo. I am currently building a Mendel90 reprap (sturdy, using MDF frame) and plan on using these oogoo feet underneath the base plate. Almost all dimensions/settings are parametric, including the number of spokes of the foot and the number of molds in the printed part. The example stls are for single mold and 2x2 mold for casting feet that can be fixed with a 3mm screw and a 10mm washer. oogoo is great stuff and easy to use, see: http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/ This is one of my first openscad designs, one of my first oogoo designs and my first published thing using my first reprap printer for making it, so don't be too tough on me..

Either create your own stl using the scad file or use one of the stls provided (for parameter descriptions see the comments in the scad file). ..1x1.stl is a mold for casting a single foot. ..2x2.stl is a mold for casting 4 feet in one go. Print the mold using your 3d printer. I have used PLA with the following slic3r settings: 0.4mm layer thickness, single perimeter, one bottom layer, one top layer, rectilinear infill 25%. After printing, mix an appropriate amount of oogoo (as the molds are fairly small, one or two tablespoons are more than enough for a single foot). I have used a silicone to starch mix of 1:1 for fast setting (see http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/ for detailed instructions on mixing oogoo). Color the oogoo using oil paints to you liking (the example feet were cast using grey silicone and some revell paint because that was all I had available). Quickly press the oogoo into the mold, a used popsicle stick works well. You need to work fast, because 1:1 oogoo sets within minutes. After filling the mold with oogoo, scrape of excess oogoo from the top of the mold. If a little bit of oogoo remains at the sides, don't worry, this will be a very thin rubber layer, which can be easily trimmed of with a pair of scissors after setting. Wait til the oogoo has set (for me, 30 minutes were enough). Using a tooth pick, carefully remove the foot from the mold. If necessary, clean up the oogoo foot with a pair of scissors.

comments.text:
I recently tried ogoo myself. Freshly made it sticks to PLA but after
curing it does not at all. By pushing small oogoo pieces into a prints
crevices instead of pushing a whole print into a block of oogoo
air-bubbles can be completely avoided. This is perfect for mold making
for poly-urethane or other resins and excellent for making hundreds of
board game pieces or other useful small identical parts.
comments.author: mechadense

comments.text: Do you think the feet will be durable enough?
comments.author: jetpad

comments.text: Well, I have to admit that after I found out about oogoo about a week ago I have gotten carried away just a little bit by the possibilities without thinking too much about technical feasibility..
comments.author: jetpad

comments.text: Dear,
comments.author: Stemer114

comments.text: After more than a year, the feet are still mounted under my printer and seem to be working ok. They have become noticeably stiffer, though. I guess one should try to minimize the starch content when making the ogoo. In my experience, the ogoo cures quite quickly even with a low starch content (1 tblspoon for a plastic cup of silicone caulk) - at least if it is mixed  thoroughly.
comments.author: Oliv4945

comments.text: Thanks. It looks like they would be good feet for something that isn't too heavy. Especially for setting it on a delicate surface. I've printed with nylon a little and think it might be a good material for feet that need to be a little more durable or are supporting something heavier.

This is a fun Halloween spool holder for almost any type of printer. It was Printed on our machines all in one day and assembles easily. As seen in the photos ball bearing will be needed, I used 24 5/16 inch ball bearings. 7 Spider leg's will be needed along with 1 pumpkin head, 1 interior bearing wheel, 1 spider interior, and 1 spider leg with filament holder. I've also used this with 8 spider legs (no filament holder) and that works as well. Hope you like this design, Happy Halloween!

description.text: This is a motorcycle that I quickly designed in Solidworks and haven't yet gotten the chance to print out or tweak that much. I should be able to snap together with only a little glue for the wheel holders. It definitely needs some work and any advice would be greatly appreciated.

To print this out you should print everything except for the wheel holder, Back wheel, and connector for wheels. These three files need to be printed twice.  Then just look at the picture and you should be able to piece it together. A few parts may need sanding/gluing depending on the accuracy of your printer. Also support is necessary for the seat, main body, and back wheel attacher. If you don't want to do all that work just print out the bed plate with supports and you should be fine.

title: Duplicator i3 fan blower adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I wanted a blower type fan for my i3 and tried a few of the ring type adapters. While they worked they were so large that I couldn't inspect the print on the bed while the system was running and they made height set up a pain in the butt. I designed this simple adapter to bolt the fan onto the existing mounting structure. This only requires the addition of one nut and bolt as it uses the original fan hardware to mount otherwise. I ordered the fan from digikey and had it in a day or 2. http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/BFB0512HH-F00/603-1115-ND/1014446 As the blower isn't near the tip you can print it in PLA.

title: InMoov hand dual track servo pulleys

description.text: Different design of the servo pulleys for the hand of the InMoov 3D printed robot. The robot is designed by Geël Langevin. You can find all the original designs at http://www.inmoov.fr. I modified the servo pulleys to have two tracks with different diameters, because the lines need to be pulled a longer distance when the hand closes than when it opens. The pulleys have 25 splines. A video of the first test can be found here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gwx3JIakDV0. Use the larger track to close the finger, and the smaller track to open it. I created on more video to show the difference between the original pulley and the new. It also contains a sequence showing th whole hand. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b5S-8hjsMr8 Updated with an alternate design, with two extra holes that can be used for screws to tension the lines.

comments.text: I like that. I will try with rubber bands on the outside. To pull on the outside should have the same effect as pushing on the inside. As it is now, the full finger may move first, or the top of the finger may move first. How it moves depends on the friction in each joint. With a spring or a rubber band en each joint, the movement should be more balanced.

author: eyedoc26

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Made more to look good than to function, although at a glance, several parts appear to be able to flex and rotate.
The arm was designed with several holes in the upper and lower arm to (presumably) hold tools. The holes were dimensioned for if this was a human-size robot, so about 1:6. (Sorry to anyone who wanted to put real screwdriver bits in the lower arm.) If this were a real robot, many parts would be able to rotate freely, and all joints would be able to flex with the visible overlapping plates. With both arms, the MakerTron should be able to reach over to grab tools from its other arm, with the upper and lower arms freely spinning. The fingers and thumb are flat towards the inside for better tool and part grasping. As a fix-it man myself, I know I'd want that. (Since these are futuristic robots, I didn't include doors for the arm holes. I figure the tools could be magnetized or the robot could have force field doors or something.) It only has three fingers because I never use my pinkie for fix-it jobs and I know a few people who can type faster than me and don't use their pinkies.
Made for Pinshape's MakerTron contest. The right arm file is a mirror of the left, made for those of you whose printer software won't let you do that.
This design is missing a hinge pin. I used wire, but you could use anything. This design is also lacking a clasp. The ring opens easily and cannot hold much inside. Other than that, it is super sweet
